segments.text: To start off with, could you give me some information about where you were born and when?
Yes, Enid, Oklahoma, January 18th, 1939.
My parents were both involved in the war.
My father graduated from Enid Flying School with Advanced Air Force Base.
He was killed as a B-17 pilot in World War II in England in 1944.
My mother flew with Amelia Earhart's WASP, so she was gone.
My grandparents raised me.
I attended schools in Enid until I was having extreme difficulty growing up like most young men in about the ninth grade.
Unlike a lot of young men, my father left me $10,000 insurance when he was killed.
That's what the government paid then for your life.
And I looked through Ladies Home Journal.
I saw a lot of advertisements for preparatory schools.
I wrote off to them, even though I was failing in the ninth grade, and received brochures back.
I don't know why they accepted me, but I went to Fork Union Military Academy in Virginia from Oklahoma and did very well there.
Whatever I may become, I have to give thanks to them because they certainly provided the foundation.
I had an appointment to West Point since that was what I went to Fork Union for.
I came back to Oklahoma, having graduated in the summer of 57, and applied for Texas A&M because, very frankly, I was burned out on gray, stiff wool uniforms.
And I just couldn't see myself starting over another four years that way.
The Texas A&M Corps, as I remember in those days, had almost 6,000.
was one of the most famous corps in the United States.
And I decided I want to be a part of the best.
That's why I applied.
But I was really a young man rolling around looking for a hole to fall into.
And before I could get down here at Texas A&M, I went over and joined the paratroops.
And that was in August of 1957.

even with all my military training the fact that i've probably forgotten more about some of the weapons having been trained in the rotc program and some of the sergeants for example my drill sergeant had been a locomotive engineer and knew nothing about what we were doing and i was always a trainee platoon sergeant in my individual and advanced training i was court-martialed twice in the first eight weeks so i got kind of started off on a bad foot even though
At the end of the first eight weeks, the command wanted to send me to OCS.
I refused to go because I wanted to be in Special Forces, more than I wanted to be an officer.
So I ended up in Special Forces at Fort Bragg as a demolitionist.
And the only reason I really became a Ranger, or became an officer, is because I wanted to be a Ranger.
And I kept applying for Ranger training, and Special Forces didn't receive Ranger training those days, since we got it as part of our normal
day-to-day duties.
Finally, Sergeant Ortiz, the 77th, said, Bo, if you want to go to Ranger school, you got to be a second lieutenant.
I said, well, make me a second lieutenant.
So he gave me the forms for OCS.
I filled them out.
I went to OCS.
I went to Ranger training.
And following that, I found out something.
I couldn't get back in Special Forces because there were no second lieutenants in Special Forces.
That's all I really cared about was being there.
So after I made first lieutenant,
I went back to Special Forces.
And then in 1964, I went to Vietnam and served four years in Vietnam.
My jobs included being the chief of reconnaissance and the intelligence officer for Project Delta, which at that time was the only one of the super secret organizations that was in operation.
Our job was to go into denied areas and obtain intelligence.
Following that, I organized at the direction of General Westmoreland the first American commanded guerrilla force.
And it was supposed to have been a volunteer operation where once we tested it, we would all get our choice of assignments.
We know how that works.
If you're successful, they want you to stay together for one more, for one more, for one more.
So four operations later, we had finally completed our guerrilla mission.
It was during that time
We recovered the U-2 that General Russ Mullen writes about in his book, A Soldier Reports.
That was just one of our training missions.
Following that, General Wyatt asked me to form a unit that could do a myriad of special activities.
For example, blowing up bridges at the Air Force where it was having difficult hitting, raiding enemy headquarters.
Gorillas are two and a half miles an hour.
They're limited by foot power.
And they don't travel very fast.
They're not very responsive.
Plus, we couldn't keep our prisoners alive.
And they wanted prisoners from various areas.
So we restructured the guerrilla command into what was called a special task force B-36.
And I formed that.
As cannon fodder, I required five Americans from each of the infantry divisions, five LURPs.
The general wanted to know if I wanted sergeants.
They were airborne ranger.
And I said, no, because the division commanders will never give them up.
Those are their prized people.
I said, I just want somebody who is long-range reconnaissance patrol qualified.
Part of my Delta duties was to train LRPS.
And so I was a chief instructor at the Rekondo School in Vietnam until we formed the guerrilla command.
B-36 was very successful at what we did.

it was at the end of four years i had just put in for an extension leave i was working for general wyatt on special operations and i went to him with a proposal because i was using cambodians i didn't speak cambodia and our missions were extremely high visibility i wanted to obtain a force that i could communicate with because frequently more fire came from behind us than came from the front of us

meaning the cambodes that followed you directly behind you were fine but those on the flanks often were behind you and didn't know what was going on so you had as much danger of being shot from the rear as you did in the front in many cases so i asked him if i could have the prisoners out of long been jail since they their lives were basically finished
And in about 30 or 60 days, I could train them as guerrillas.
And they spoke English.
And we could probably have increased our productivity some 300, 400%.
It was at that time that Wyatt changed my mind and showed me the light about Vietnam.
He said, quote, Bo, stop trying to win the war.
You're not going to win it.
I'm not going to win it.
Use this war to benefit your career.
He said, be ahead of your contemporaries.
Come up on the general staff.
I'll give you a job here.
Use the war to get your promotions earlier than those that aren't over here.
And it just thunderstruck me because we were in the field dying and trying.
And I said to him, yes, sir, I know that I can't win the war by myself, and even you as the daddy rabbit can't win it.
But if we don't try every day as hard as we can, the thing will never be over.
But I realized then that he had, being the commander, he knew things that I didn't know.
There was no intent of winning that war.
And I decided instantly that I would not be responsible for one life, one limb, one liberty being lost again.
So I left Vietnam and came back to the United States very disillusioned.
And it's ironic, because over my headquarters, some of my sergeants had placed this plaque that we took with us, my headquarters, wherever we happened to set up in the jungle.
But it had four lines.
The first line said, we come because we believe.
And that's true.
We were all there because we believed in what we were doing.
The second line said, we leave because we're disillusioned.
And that's precisely what I did.
The third line, I almost succumbed to, too.
It said, we return because we're lost.
And the last line said, we die because we're committed.
And that is exactly what happened to many of those brave soldiers there who stayed with me over those periods of time.
They'd get disillusioned.
They'd go home.
Next thing you know, here they'd be back again.
The next thing you know, they're in a body bag.
And I almost succumbed.
fit that scenario myself.
When you come back from the war, what does the Army do with you?
Most 19-year-old kids who came back, and that's what the average age was in Vietnam, flew.
It took them 19 hours to get in the combat zone to Travis Air Force Base.
When they got there, they were given a piece of paper and said, thank you, patted on the ass, and left to figure out what had happened to them for the last year.
And in that very traumatic
part of their life.
When most kids were going to trade school, going to college, or figuring out what they wanted to be when they grow up, these kids were over there watching their friends get their heads blown off.
And it affects you, especially at that young age.
I was a professional, had been through every combat school that the military had when I went there.
I was prepared for Vietnam, except I hadn't had that acid test.
I craved it.
I was there because I should have been there.
and because I wanted to be there.
At any rate, I was really affected at four years of doing nothing but killing the enemy every day.
It's a very, for lack of a better term, fearful when I thought about coming back to the United States.
What do those people have in common with me?
What is my role there?
Who am I there?
I knew who I was in Vietnam.
I knew what my role was.
It was very clear.
What am I going to do in the United States?
How do I relate?
Because to me that was the unreal world.
We were committed in Vietnam, committed to winning that war, and whatever that meant.
So when I came back, the Army was very good to me.
They first of all sent me to a year and a half of Chinese language school.
God knows that was the hardest thing that I've ever done.
I guess for damn near 18 hours a day, because that's what it takes to study Chinese.
trying to defuse me, bring my RPMs down from red line to idle.
And following that, I went to Command General Staff College.
I graduated, honored graduate of the Command General Staff College.
When I finished that, again, I applied for duty in Vietnam.
And my best friend, who will be the chief of staff in the Army someday, said, Bo, please don't go back there.
And I see now that it perfectly met that equation.
We returned because we're lost.
And I said, no, I've got to go back over there.
As long as that war is there, I cannot have let my friends have died in vain.
We must win that war.
He talked me out of that.
He said, Bo, that's crap.
Stay here.
You're only going to lose over there.
And I listened to him.
I listened to him again when he told me to marry the wife that I have now.
And he was right about that, too.
So anyway, the Army sent me to school, having gone through about three years of defusing.
But even when I was in the Command General Staff College, I, at nighttime, would shoot the lights out in the town of Leavenworth.
I'm sure the prison geared up 100 times when I would come home at night.
Tucson, Arizona didn't have very many streetlights in it.
I didn't put bullet holes through.
For about three years as a field grade officer, I was doing things like that because it was still the year of the gun.
And people just tolerated me.
I guess I never had any trouble with anybody.
I threw colonels over the bar at Fort Leavenworth.
It was just the nature of the beast then.
So...
And then ironically enough I was given a job on the art.
Well, I was supposed to go with Nixon to China Because he was when he made his trip over there.
He was going over to establish a US mission He thought but the Chinese weren't ready for that yet So I was selected as because they didn't have an old seven which was a Brigadier General.
They were looking for that spoke Chinese they tagged me to go and Then it fell apart because the Chinese weren't going to cooperate with Nixon that quickly
As a result, I said, what do I do now?
I had jobs because I had graduated high in the CNGS, any place I wanted it.
I ended up on the Army General Staff working for General Westmoreland.
He said he wanted someone as a spokesman for the Army who had decorations on their chest and not a journalist.
And his job, even though he hated it at that time, he directly opposed it, was to sell the Modern Volunteer Army.
And it was my job to act as
as his spokesman in doing that.
I believed in it, because I didn't want anything but volunteers around me.
But he showed me where I was very tunnel visioned.
And where the modern volunteer army doesn't work, we should have the draft.

And he's right, because we have cut out that cross-section of American society that keeps America interested in what the military is doing and keeps the army a part of society instead of apart from it.
So at any rate, at that time, General Abrams came on board.
And Abrams hated special forces.
And so he took one look at me and said, I've got nothing to say to you.
And a good friend of mine, General Seidel, asked me, he said, Bo, how would you like to go to school?
So again, when they don't have anything for a soldier to do, they send him to school.
As a result, I became highly degreed as a victim of circumstance, and I really haven't used any of the scholastic talents other than the bits of trivia that help you in your day-to-day life.
After finishing the school, I was selected to go down and command the Special Forces in Panama, and I did that for two years.
It was there that General Harold R. Aaron, who was a major general then, first contacted me.
He was the chief of military intelligence then.
He came to Panama and he asked me to think about how we might be able to gain information on American POWs in Southeast Asia.
It totally dumbfounded me because I was a commander of special forces in Panama.
I was concerned only about Latin America, the strategic protection of the Canal Zone,
and all this other kind of crap.
He was talking about last life, you know, Vietnam.
And I remember when he left, I told my intelligence officer, Randy Young, the general's clutches slipping.
You know, he's back in Vietnam.
I was inexplicably transferred to the Office of the Secretary of Defense, much against General McAuliffe, who was the sink south.
Objections.
He wanted me to stay down there in Panama, but...
OSD, somebody pressed a button.
I ended up going to the Defense Security Assistance Agency as the Congressional Relations Chief.
And General Fish was my commander there.
When I said, what the hell am I doing in Washington, D.C. as Congressional Relations?
I'm a jungle fighter.
And he said, Bo, you'll find your assignment here is much like that that you're used to, the jungles of Washington.
are just different in that they're concrete, but they're still insidious, and they're still dangerous, and we need your kind of skills here.
The committee that I worked with was a foreign relations committee, both in the House and the Senate.
They have oversight for the POW issue.
It was in October of 1978 when Aaron came to me.
Now he's a lieutenant general, and the number two man in the Defense Intelligence Agency said,
Bo, we've got overwhelming evidence that Americans are still being held.
We'd like you to consider retirement so that you can work through the private sector because the Carter administration has politically handcuffed us from doing anything about the POW issue.
I was to take a hiatus in my military career.
It didn't turn out that way.
It's been five years.
I will not go back in uniform.
I don't think.
The reason the FBI asked me in January of 1983, Bo, are you ready to come back in uniform now?
I said, no.
He said, why?
I said, because the job's not over.
And I caveated that further by saying, I don't think I will either.
And the guy says, why not?
Because at the time of my retirement, I was at the very good times of your career.
You work hard in the Army to finally get someplace.
And I had finally gotten to the point where the Army was going to be fun for me.

and then to give it up right at that time didn't make sense matter of fact army times ran a big front page article when i retired that said it was a surprise it was and nobody believed the reasons i gave and they were right but i couldn't tell them why i retired at that time bottom line is that it is far more important that this issue be resolved correctly
for the good of the nation than it is for any one person to have fun with the Army.
And for that reason, as an urge in my conscience, I cannot quit until this thing is resolved satisfactorily.
I will not quit.
So far I've had no one ask me to quit.
I think that secretly each one of the people in the bureaucracy hopes that we will succeed.

I know that not so secretly, many people in the military, especially Fort Bragg, my contemporaries, embrace me when I go to see them in the Pentagon, are praying that we will be successful because they know what we're doing is right.
So that's without stopping.

a capsule of what's gone down go ahead and get specific now okay when you were in vietnam in 1964 and you were doing your specific years this specific mission down there um what positive advantages came about through being involved with all these ambushes and attacks what what advantages do you feel the advantage yeah the advantage was that uh
It taught me lessons about life that you'll never learn in the philosophy or theology books.
You learn what life is about.
Many of the parables that you read in the Bible become clear to you once you have experienced the realities of snuffing out human life with a mere pound and a half's pressure

trigger or claymore mine you realize and I knew a couple of times that I was I was approaching insanity over there from that point of view when suddenly you would see a man that was a living human being who had a family just like yours who had aspirations and hope for life
One moment when you're in ambush, he is there thinking, living, feeling, and the next moment he's garbage, laying along the trail.
It makes you realize that something is not right about it.
And as a soldier, you're doing your job.
Thank God, because when I finished the war, when I left, I had a terrible time, as I said, coming back to the United States, trying to find
My handhold here.
One of the first things I did is I came back and I went home to Tucson, Arizona, where my mother then lived, and tried to come to grips before my language school started.
I had about a month and a half.
I ended up going up on a mountain in northern Mexico by myself because there was nobody here who could help me.
Nobody here knew what my problem was.
Nobody had ever been a part of it.
I married a Chinese girl and brought her back with me, a Chinese ethnic, Vietnamese origin, because she was the only one who knew who I was.
She was my identity.
She knew how hard we had tried.
She knew my friends who had died.
I needed her as my ID card.
It didn't work out, even though I did get two wonderful kids from her.
But I went up on the mountain to find out, one, if there was a chance that I had a life,
I was raised in Pentecostal churches in Oklahoma, and you're not supposed to kill people, let alone hundreds of them.
And you have to reconcile yourself.
When I went up there, I took one bullet in my 9mm, not to protect me against the wolves, because certainly if they were going to eat you, they were going to eat you.
But as a final determiner,
If I couldn't have reconciled myself and saw that I do have a good life to live, then I would have started as quickly as I could whatever comes after.
The fact is that a lot of things did come very clear to me, I had to answer the questions
Why do people die like that?
Is it all right for a soldier to take those lives?
Why do babies have to die?
There are all kinds of those questions that many Vietnam vets had to answer.
I was lucky enough because I had the intelligence.
I went up there.
I got those answers.
When I came down, I was a whole human being again.
I was still pretty frisky, like I say.
I shot out a lot of streetlights.
I threw a lot of people over the bars, but I was settled in my life.
That saved me.
So Vietnam gave me a positive thing in that it gave me the secret to life, and that is a paradox.
Many things are paradoxes about combat.
If you're going to live, you must choose the road to death.
That may not sound right.
But it simply means if you're going to live, you can't be thinking about home.
You can't be thinking about wife, family, D-Rose.
Before I would go on a mission, I would see myself being killed in every conceivable way.
That way I had already died by parachute crashing into the trees or into a band of cobras or being blown apart as I hung in the trees by the enemy machine gunner.
Having already died those ways, then there's no place for the enemy's bullet.
And so when you go into combat, you have chosen the road to death.
You're much more alert.
Hopefully the enemy is thinking about home or what he's going to do when he gets back.
And in that moment is when the bullet enters his brain and stops his life.
So there are many of those paradoxes, but yes, there are.
I gained the secret of life through learning about death.
What specifically did you do in Vietnam, and what unit were you in?
Okay, to give you specifics, when I first went over there, I organized a camp called Sui Da.
Sui Da means Rock Creek.
It's next to Nui Ba Den Mountain, which is very famous in Vietnam as a shrine.
Nui Ba Den means the Black Virgin Mountain.
My unit was called A322.

Later, I went to Delta Project as the first officer who was the reconnaissance chief, and I was called Detachment B-52, and I was the reconnaissance chief and the intelligence officer for Project Delta.
Then I was the chief instructor of the McVie Recondo School.
Following that, I formed
The guerrilla task force called 957.
That means 21 as blackjack as a winner.
That's why it came about like that.
Later, it turned into Detachment B-36, Special Task Force B-36.
And later, that turned into the 3rd Mobile Strike Command.
If you look in the lineage of Vietnam, I formed each one of those units.
And then after they were formed, I eventually left them.
I left the 3rd Mobile Strike Command after becoming disillusioned in November of 1968.
And I was the commander of each one of them.
Each one of them contained American troops.
I had one of the very unique commands in Vietnam.
In B-36, for example, I had five companies of Chinese that we used as security forces.
I had eight companies of Cambodians that we used as guerrilla forces.
I had about 50 American special forces that made up special teams.
And I had five LURPs from each infantry division that made up my reconnaissance unit.
And I had a team of SAS from the Australians.
So I had a real cross-section of everybody there.
So that's what it was all about.
What was the motivation, your motivation to your valor in Vietnam in which you received all these 60 decorations?
Just doing the job.
It's very hard for Special Forces to be decorated in Vietnam.
The reason is because in the divisions, a two-star general is authorized to give up to a silver star.
We had no two-star generals in Special Forces.
So if we were going to get a decoration, General Westmoreland had to give it.
General Westmoreland didn't have much time, being the daddy rabbit, to deal with Special Forces.
So much of the things that Special Forces did went totally unsung.
For example, we got nothing for recovering the U-2.
You'd have thought that would have been a big deal.
It was big enough for him to single it out as the example of the American soldier, but no decorations were given for that U-2 operation.
Nobody thinks about the soldier when he's doing his job.

we were just there doing the job trying to win the war and the decorations that i received came from generals that we worked for because they were astounded by our work general hay commanding general first division for example gave me two silver stars in in one day and said bo i wish that there was some higher decoration we could give your command he lined my whole command up and awarded silver stars
He said, but this is the highest award I can give you.
He says, what you people are doing is amazing.
I don't know how you do that.
He said, what do you eat, for example?
I pulled out a package of indigenous ration, which was dried rice and minnows.
He said, God, we could never feed Americans that.
But see, he forgets that special forces are Americans, too.
So the lines of our motto,
We came because we believed.
We were there because we believed in each other.
And once you start it, it is a continuous cycle.
How do you end it?
We had to make sure, it seemed to me, that the men who had sacrificed their life, their limbs, their liberties, didn't do so in vain.
That meant one thing, victory.
There is no in-between.
It's victory or it's defeat.
And I was resolved to stay there the duration, plus six, whatever that meant.
One of the big mistakes we made in Vietnam was that we sent generals there for one year.
And a general going there for one year figured, geez, if I don't do anything, maybe I won't do anything wrong.
And the generals should have all gone there, like we did in World War II.
You come home when the job is done.
But we were trying to get everybody through the combat experience.
Everybody came over there looking to enhance their career by spending one year in a combat zone.
And then, like General Wyant said, using it as part of your ticket punching to get ahead of your contemporaries.
So I had all my tickets punched.
I got advanced degrees.
I've been on the Army general staff, the Office of the Secretary of Defense staff, all of the Army schools where I graduated, honored graduate from.
And even all that ticket punching isn't enough to override my conscience, because I know what must be done in this case.
And I was wrong about Vietnam.
We shouldn't have been there.
being there we should have won it and it was only when i realized that was impossible that i was not going to continue to throw good energy after bad and i quit
You just mentioned the generals.
If we could do it all over again, what do you feel the United States should do to win the war?
Well, I think the first thing is the United States should not have fought a war in the first place.
I think the United States has an obligation to wake up.
I'm so damn mad at the American people because we have become a nation of spectators.
We lay back and we love to be entertained, but we've forgotten and we criticize the government.
But the government is of the people, by the people, and for the people.
And we forget that.
Those people working in Washington, D.C. are elected by us and work for us.
If they do something wrong, damn it, it's our fault.
And participative government has become a thing of the past.
And so if we educate ourselves, we are obligated as a nation to know what the hell is going on.
If we would have done our homework about Vietnam, we would have found out that we should have never been there in the first place.
In 1944, Ho Chi Minh embraced us.
The OSS trained Ho Chi Minh.
We gave him equipment.
He loved the Americans.
The war was won in 1945.
Instead of the United States taking over the...
the transition of government in Southeast Asia, they turned it over to the British because our primary effort was in Japan and in Europe.
When the British took over, it was decided for some moment of insanity that we would give the control of Southeast Asia back to the French.
Ho Chi Minh then tapped us on the shoulder and says, what are you doing?
Are you going to stand by and let them recolonize our countries?
We should have our independence.
The Japanese gave us the independence, for Christ's sake.
But the United States would not intervene.
We didn't even weigh in with the British in De Gaulle about that.
We just turned our head away from Ho Chi Minh and said, sorry, we can't hear you, Ho.
As a result, the French took over again.
As a result, Ho Chi Minh begged us for support.
We wouldn't give it to him.
So he went to the people who would.
He hated the Soviets, but they gave him the support.
He fought the French, and he defeated them.
And then here we come, right in their wake.
If we would have done our homework and been educated, we would have never sent a steel helmet to Vietnam anyway.
Special forces should have gone because that's the way to do it.
We do it in a very low-profile, professional manner, small groups.
I should have been in Vietnam, but 56,000 19-year-olds should not have been that lost their life because a white face under a steel helmet
gives every reason for a good, loyal Vietnamese, no matter where he is, to rally around the flag to get the hated Yankee out of his country.
I was the intelligence officer for Delta Project.
I saw that the North Vietnamese didn't start coming into the South until the Marines came over, until the Big Red One came over.
When those steel helmets started arriving, the North Vietnamese built up in like numbers, and so began the Vietnam War.
I don't think that would have happened.

we wouldn't have sent those 19 year olds and it was a political war soldiers should not fight political wars politicians should when the politicians are not going to fight a political war then you fight a military war we could have won that war easily but we didn't because it wasn't a military victory we were interested in it was a political victory
How did you feel coming back to the United States with the resentment against the war?
I didn't care about that.
It's a free country.
And I almost got angry one day.
I was in a school auditorium.
And when we stood to say the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag, there was a black kid sitting directly in front of me who was long and gangly, about 6'5", obviously a young kid.
And he refused to stand up.
For a moment, I felt like pumping him on the back of his head because his mother was there and she was trying to get him to stand up.
He wouldn't do it.
Then I suddenly realized this is what we fight and die for.
So this scumbag can sit here and act like an asshole.
And I don't care.
The dissenters were right, but for all the wrong reasons.
The people who ran off to Canada were right, but for all the wrong reasons.
They shouldn't have done it then.
They should have spoken with one voice like the enemy did.
But they may have seen something that I didn't see.
Muhammad Ali, he went with his conscience.
He did what I think is probably right.
He did it the right way.
He says, I'm not going to fight.
But he didn't run off to Canada either.
The fact is that our country was wrong.
But at that time, we didn't know that.
And past is always prologue and it's always 20-20 hindsight.
But
We didn't know that we were wrong then.
So the dissenters were wrong.
The protesters were wrong.
They were right in the end, but they were right for the wrong reasons.
But I didn't care about them.
Nobody ever bothered me.
And it's funny, in the book General Westmoreland wrote, the Pentagon advised me to refuse to allow him to use that story
And they said the reason was because a lot of nuts were going to look me up, probably.
But nobody ever had.
I think it's because they think I'll probably kill them.
War-crazed Vietnam vet.
In all my POW efforts, some nice guy saved a movie star's life in Hollywood from being mugged.
The guy had to change his phone to move out of town because he got so many death threats.
I've never gotten one nut call on the phone.
I've never gotten one letter that was a nut letter.
I think it's because, I don't know why, maybe there's the aura, a threat, that they think I'll track them down or something.
In San Francisco, people talk bad about the demonstrations there.
I never bought a meal in San Francisco.
When I came home from Vietnam, we were always in uniform.
I used to eat breakfast there, the biggest breakfast I could get.
And that was normally when we went over, ate breakfast.
When I came back, it was usually in the evening.
I'd eat supper there.

never every time i would eat i would finish i'd get ready to pay and the waitress would tell me sir your meal has already been paid for and when i would ask and this happened god i was back across the river about 10 times because six months was each extension that you took and i was there for four years she would say sir your meal has already been paid for it was always anonymous
So San Francisco was beautiful to me.
I went to Las Vegas because I wanted to see a show one time when I'd come home to Vietnam.
I didn't realize you had to have tickets months in advance.
When I got there with my family, there was a long line, and then there was a no line.
So I went up to the no line because I thought the long line was to buy tickets.
It wasn't.
The long line was people already had tickets.
The no line was people to buy them, but it was for, like, next year.
But the maitre d' asked me.
He says, you just come back from Vietnam?
And I said, yes.
He said, just a minute.
He took me and my family down.
We sat right in the front row.
We got everything on the house.
So I was always treated with great respect as a soldier.
I never had none of the negative experiences that I hear other people relate.
And I think maybe it's your attitude.
Who would have dared to have chastised me to my face?
Maybe I was a crazed Vietnam veteran.
Maybe I would have destroyed them.
I don't know.
Whatever it is, it didn't happen.
So I didn't care about the protesters.
I thought it was kind of humorous.
When I worked on Army General Staff, I would watch the hippies, and they were totally disorganized.
Thousands of them would form.
Literally, the third human seed would form outside of the Pentagon.
Then they would start running for the Pentagon.
But they started running way too far back.
I knew they'd never make it.
They were all going to be tired out by the time they got to where the GSA police were.
So here would come the human sea, running just like they probably did at the Battle of Bull Run over the green plains of the Pentagon.
Then out from the side of the Pentagon would ride the park police with their horses, tear gas, and their billy clubs.
And God, it was hair, eyes, and teeth all over the place.
And what those poor hippies didn't know was inside the Pentagon, you know, there was another battalion of military police.
They didn't stand a chance from the beginning.
And then I used to laugh because they would chain themselves at the door of the Pentagon.

And in the wintertime, it was always my suggestion that we help them, that we put a set of handcuffs on them, because what would happen when they got cold, they'd unlock the chains and they'd go get warm.
So I said, let's just put our own handcuffs on them as long as they're chained and let them stay overnight maybe.
When I went to the American University, I silently protested myself.
I went to the American University, and it was funny.
I got two master's degrees there, one by being a victim of a service, one was because of Abraham.
The other was I finished school, and I never paid much attention to the regulations, so I didn't check in with the Army all the time.
When I graduated, they didn't know I was going to graduate, so they had no job for me.
So I had to go back for another year and take another sequence.
While I was there, my silent protest was that I would, being an intelligence officer, I've been trained in both safe lock manipulation and conventional locks.
I would change the locks on some of the hippies while they were demonstrating.
I'd change the locks on their bicycles.
and just change them around.
And then until I had to go to class, I'd sit and watch them become frustrated and furious because the combination wasn't working or the key wouldn't work in their lock.
I don't know what they ever did.
They'd chain them up real good, and I'd chain the lock around.
That's my way of protesting what they were doing.
But I never had any vindictiveness.
I didn't give a damn about that.
Why did you get involved with your mission in 1972 when you were assigned to Panama to train Latin American soldiers in the special forces techniques?
Yeah, it was in 72.
That's a wrong thing.
I went to Panama in 1975.
I returned in 1977.
I went there because the Army selected me as a commander.
of Special Forces in Panama.
It was that simple.
And I must say that before I went, because you've got to realize I'd been on the Army General Staff, which was a puke assignment.
Before that, I'd been a Command General of Staff, College of the University of Nebraska, a year and a half of Chinese.
You know, I was academic.
When I finally, my wife thought I was a karate instructor, because if she never saw me in a uniform, I went for two years to the American University.
My dad was fully paid by the service.
I told her, I said, I'm really a soldier.
Someday I'm going to have to go back to work.
And I did.
Before I got ready to go to Panama, knowing what was down there, I went back up on the mountain again and made sure that that was exactly what I wanted to do.
And I was born to be a soldier.
I don't know how many lifetimes I've lived as a soldier, but that's what my purpose is in this life.
And so I took that assignment.
It was the best assignment in the Army.
And I enjoyed it.
I did a damn good job down there with it.
And I look forward to doing it again when I was reassigned to the Pentagon and would have had I not been asked to retire.
My next job would have been the 10th Group Commander, which is something I always wanted to do.

um what motivated you to get involved with the powmia problem because i was asked by general aaron and when i thought about it it was really it was really shocking and depressing jesus is it possible that this great nation of ours could have for political reasons let

live americans dropped between the cracks and when i thought about it and having worked as a chief of congressional relations i suddenly realized you damn right it was possible and once you get involved with it it's something you can't put down for a long time i couldn't eat a meal i couldn't go to sleep at night unless i thought about the condition of those men after a while you get fairly hardened to it
I've been to Laos three times now, setting up the rescue.
We will rescue them.
We're going to do it soon.
But it certainly is possible.
I used to not think that the president even went to the bathroom.
I thought he was totally invulnerable to all of the human frailties.
That's wrong.
He is only going to do what, like any other servant, what we make him do.
And that's why the president has discovered POWs in 1983.
Not because they didn't know about them, but because the American people has finally brought it

to national attention to the point where all the politicians see they better start looking at it so i got interested in it because i was invited i would have loved to have forgotten about the vietnam war i was very happy in panama i didn't even think about vietnam and to revisit a lot of those experiences was not pleasant for me
And to, I don't want to lance the festering wound of war that has been healing for 10 years now.
But if you must lance it to let it heal cleanly, then let's lance it.
This issue is much like a cancer.
The politicians are like people who, even though the sickness has been diagnosed,
They don't want to hear it.
They don't want to treat it because the treatment is onerous and very difficult.
But it's a cancer that I think can strangle our moral standards in this country.
If they strangle our moral standards, if it erodes that underpinning, what's going to hold us up as a country?
So I think that it is so important that

like a patient who does have a cancer or sickness we do whatever we have to do to treat it and to get well and that's why i will as anyone who loves a relative and i love this country i'm going to continue to strive to persuade to do what i have to until we do get well on this issue look at watergate if you would have asked nixon
he would have told you, don't do this.
As a matter of fact, he did tell us that, because you're going to completely erode the American image in the world.
And it was a dark period in our history to think that the president was a crook and a liar.
But you know something?
We emerged a better nation because of it.
Now when you travel overseas, foreigners are amazed that in America not even the president can lie and get away with it.
And so it's going to be a dark time in our history when we have to reopen the wounds of war in Vietnam.
But damn it, we're going to emerge a stronger nation than we were before because of it.
Our moral backbone is going to be reinforced.
And we're going to be stronger because we did the right thing instead of sticking our head in the sand and letting the cancer eventually kill us.

What do you say to those critics that say that the government should more or less take this job over and that you're just a private citizen and you're just trying to do your own thing and you're disturbing international relations?
First of all, I'm bulletproof to all criticism because if you're not in the arena getting bloodied and dirty, then you don't count.
If you're willing to get in the arena, then...
